subject: Re: [junit] assertEquals(Object, Object)
msgSnippet: ... I m not sure, but is it possible that you mistake transitivity for reflexivity? If a.equals(b) and b.equals(c) then it s also true to say a.equals(c). With
messageBody:
-----BEGIN PGP SIGNED MESSAGE-----

On Fri, 10 May 2002 21:13:21 +0300, Alexander Zynevich wrote:

>it seems to me that these methods does not test transitivity
>of equals, which is declared in Java Specification. I think
>documentation should state that assertEquals(p1,p2) is
>completely equiv to assertTrue(p1.equals(p2))

I'm not sure, but is it possible that you mistake transitivity
for reflexivity?

If a.equals(b) and b.equals(c) then it's also true to say
a.equals(c). With a method with only two parameters it's not
possible to prove transitivity, so I don't think that this
must be mentioned in the documentation.


Regards, Lothar

- --
